root.pub-comments: Kam-Sui consists of more than these two languages, however I've only included the relevant languages as discussed in the source.
root.publications: Yang, Quan. 1988. Developmental Tendencies in Kam Phonology. In Jerold A. Edmondson & David B. Solnit, Comparative Kadai: Linguistic studies beyond Tai, 27-42. ISBN 0-88312-066-6

child.pub-comments: For the geographical regions of each dialect, I have used the regions for which the dialect groups seem to have been named. The source only states explicitly the regions for a few of these dialects, but the author uses a specific form for there. For example, he first calls Rongjiang Zhanglu "Guizhou Province Rongjiang County Zhanglu vernacular," so it is safe to assume that all of the vernacular names refer to place names. Furthermore, because these varieties seem to be named after the area in which they are spoken, their names may resemble the names for other Tai-Kadai or non-Tai-Kadai languages and varieties spoken in the same geographical region.
child.publications: Yang, Quan. 1988. Developmental Tendencies in Kam Phonology. In Jerold A. Edmondson & David B. Solnit, Comparative Kadai: Linguistic studies beyond Tai, 27-42. ISBN 0-88312-066-6

child.pub-comments: This source did not discuss the dialects of Sui. I've included this language because it is referenced in the text, and I have also included Kam-Sui as a way of placing Kam in its appropriate family.
child.publications: Yang, Quan. 1988. Developmental Tendencies in Kam Phonology. In Jerold A. Edmondson & David B. Solnit, Comparative Kadai: Linguistic studies beyond Tai, 27-42. ISBN 0-88312-066-6
